normalised: I remember the day I finally decided to take the plunge and apply for a personal loan. I needed rupee two lakh fifty thousand urgently. My sister, Priya, was getting married and as her older brother, I felt responsible for contributing significantly. Savings weren't enough.

unnormalised: I remember the day I finally decided to take the plunge and apply for a personal loan. I needed ₹2,50,000 urgently. My sister, Priya, was getting married and as her older brother, I felt responsible for contributing significantly. Savings weren’t enough.
normalised: Like most middle-class Indians, I was initially hesitant. Loan E-M-I's always seemed daunting. But Priya's happiness was paramount. So, I started researching. I compared interest rates across different banks – S-B-I, H-D-F-C, I-C-I-C-I – reading through pages of fine print on their websites. The rates varied from nine point five percent to twelve point five percent per annum. It was confusing, to say the least.

unnormalised: Like most middle-class Indians, I was initially hesitant. Loan EMI’s always seemed daunting. But Priya's happiness was paramount. So, I started researching. normalised: Finally, I settled on a loan from I-C-I-C-I Bank, offering a rate of ten point two five percent on a five year tenure. The E-M-I worked out to around rupee five thousand three hundred per month. It seemed manageable, especially since I anticipated a bonus around Diwali. The loan processing fee was rupee two thousand plus G-S-T.

unnormalised: Finally, I settled on a loan from ICICI Bank, offering a rate of 10.25% on a 5 yr tenure. The EMI worked out to around Rs. 5300 per month. It seemed manageable, especially since I anticipated a bonus around Diwali. The loan processing fee was Rs. 2000 + GST.
normalised: The application process was surprisingly smooth. I submitted my Aadhaar card, P-A-N card, salary slips, and bank statements – the usual K-Y-C documentation. Within a week, the loan was approved, and the amount was credited to my account.

normalised: There were times when I felt the pinch, especially when unexpected expenses cropped up. Like when my scooter needed urgent repairs, costing me rupee three thousand five hundred. Or when I had to prepone a trip back home to Guwahati due to my father's health scare. But I was determined to stay on track. I made it a point to pay my E-M-I on time every month, usually around the fifth or sixth of the month. I even considered prepaying a small amount (say rupee ten thousand) during bonus season, but then my Mom insisted on gold bangles for Priya and that went straight out of the window.
